heisig_chinese_memo: Three horizontal strokes representing the number three. Or think of it as one plus two equals three.
heisig_story: And like the Roman numeral III, which triples the numeral I, the kanji for three simply triples the single horizontal stroke. In writing it, think of "1 + 2 = 3" (ä¸€ + äºŒ = ä¸‰) in order to keep the middle stroke shorter.
koohiiStory2: THREE measurements define the female shape: BUST, WAIST, and HIPS. Waist is the smallest, and for most women the HIPS are wider than the chest.

WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: This kanji is made up of the ground radical (which also happens to be the kanji for "one") and the radical for two. Combine one and two together and what do you get? Three!
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: This one should be pretty self explanatory! Even easier, you can look at this kanji and see it has three straight lines. You know what one looks like. You know what two looks like. So... this is three!
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: Three is the number of chances you get with Santa-san (ã•ã‚“). He has a list, and when you get to three "naughty things" lines, that's it. You're on Santa-san's three strikes and you're out list.
WaniKani_Reading_Info: Picture Santa-san sitting at his desk at the North Pole, eating cookies, and marking one, two, then finally three lines next to names. Once the third line appears, the kid doesn't get presents anymore.

chinese_mnemonics_deck__story: Three horizontal strokes representing the number three. Or think of it as one plus two equals three.
origin_of_ch_char_book: Before the invention of Hanzi (Chinese characters), the Chinese used knots (rope) or simple symbols. As the society became more complex, the need for more efficient ways for communication were needed. Hanzi (Chinese characters) were developed to meet such needs. What did the early writers think to express number â€œoneâ€? As children use their fingers to count, the ancient people used twigs and sticks to express numbers and to count. A twig (ä¸€, yi, one), two twigs (äºŒ, er, two), three twings (ä¸‰, san, three) four twigs (å››, si=ssu, four) became the letters from 1 to 4. Branches used for telling fortunes or for calculation (14th-19th century) However, â€œoneâ€ ä¸€ (yi, one) does not simply mean the number one in the numerical sense. In AD 100, a Chinese scholar wrote a book â€œShuo Wen Jie Ziâ€ which provides many explanations behind Hanzi. Among over 9,000 Hanzi characters in this book, the â€œone (ä¸€)â€ is explained first as followed: â€œIn the beginning there was only One Way, and this Way divided earth from heaven and made everything.â€ As we can see, â€œoneâ€ is not just a simple tree twig. It is also philosophically understood as the â€œsole principleâ€ from which heaven, earth and living things originate d from.
humanum_full_description_en:
Elaboration: The number " three " is marked with three horizontal lines. The numbers " one " to " four " are all counted horizontally, and Xu Zhongshu thinks horizontal portraits count.

" Three " represents the number of words in addition to " three ", but also often represent the majority, such as " and " like a hand, draw only three fingers on behalf of all the fingers. " Rain " only draws three points of rain, " fruit " only draws three fruits, and " Peng " only draws three strokes like drums (Zhang Bingquan).

Oracle indicates the cardinal number (the number of things), "Collection" 10109: "three cows". Zhongzha Qigui Ding: "Bei Sanpeng", " Pei " is ancient currency, ten shells is a penny, "Pei Sanpeng" means thirty shells. It also indicates the ordinal number, the third, "Collection" 37494: "Only (in) March". Song Ding: "Yu (Only) Three Years and Five Months".

"Three armies" refers to the upper army, the middle army, and the lower army. The uncle bell: "The surviving woman (ru) is governed by our army." "Three things" refers to the officials in the court (Bai Chuanjing). As opposed to "Sifang", ordering Fangyi: "The king ordered Zhou Gongzi to protect Yin and three things and four directions." It means that the king ordered Zhou Gongzi to govern the court officials and Sifang. One said that "three things" means that there are three ğ¤”² (Siweizhi), and Fang Yi: "Participate in ğ¤”²: ğ¤”²åœŸ (apprentice), ğ¤”² horse, ğ¤”² work (empty)." See " ğ¤”² ". "Three longevity" refers to longevity, middle longevity, and low longevity. It refers to longevity in general, and "three longevity" means to pray for longevity and virtue. "Health Sutra": "The upper life is one hundred and twenty, the middle life is one hundred years, and the next life is eighty." "Poetry. Lu Song. "Yigong": "Three-shou-shou is a friend", which means that you can be equal to the third-shou (Qu Wanli).

"Said Wen": "Three, the way of heaven, earth and man. Count from three. All three belongings are from three. Yi, ancient prose three follow Yi."
humanum_short_description_en: Jia Jin inscriptions are marked with the number " three " with three horizontal lines.

Basic explanation of words
three
sÄn
Several names, two plus one (the capitalized "three" generation is often used on banknotes and receipts): three-dimensional space. Trilogy. Three Kingdoms (names of Chinese dynasties).
Indicates multiple or majority: think twice. Be silent.

Radicals: ä¸€, äºŒ  (ground, two)
Meaning Mnemonic
This kanji is made up of the ground radical (which also happens to be the kanji for "one") and the radical for two. Combine one and two together and what do you get? Three!
This one should be pretty self explanatory! Even easier, you can look at this kanji and see it has three straight lines. You know what one looks like. You know what two looks like. So... this is three!
Reading Mnemonic
Three is the number of chances you get with Santa-san (ã•ã‚“). He has a list, and when you get to three "naughty things" lines, that's it. You're on Santa-san's three strikes and you're out list.
Picture Santa-san sitting at his desk at the North Pole, eating cookies, and marking one, two, then finally three lines next to names. Once the third line appears, the kid doesn't get presents anymore.
